
5. Object-Oriented programming with Ruby {#_idParaDest-139}
========================================

::: {#_idContainer218 .Content}
:::

::: {#_idContainer262 .Content}
Overview

By the end of this chapter you will be able to describe the basics of
object-oriented programming using Ruby; model data with classes;
implement instance and class variables in Ruby programs; write instance
and class methods in application programs; and evaluate getters and
setters in Ruby.


Introduction {#_idParaDest-140}
============

::: {#_idContainer262 .Content}
In the previous chapter, we studied different methods and parameters of
Ruby. We also learned about the built-in libraries of `Math`{.literal}
and `Time`{.literal} in Ruby. It was here that we began to introduce the
concepts of classes and modules. In this chapter, we will dive deeper
into Ruby classes using object-oriented programming (OOP) concepts as
our guide.

OOP is where the rubber meets the road in programming. In other words,
this is where the action happens. If you want to write a quick script or
a full-fledged application, the chances are you will use OOP. OOP has
the following benefits:

-   It is easy to design programs, as OOP concepts help greatly in the
    organization of concepts in everyday life.
-   It breaks hard problems down into manageable pieces for coding.
-   It is easy to test.
-   It is easy for others to read and learn how the program works.
-   It provides foundational units that can be easily extended or built
    upon, so as to construct robust applications.

OOP facilitates writing code in a way that allows you to think about,
and model, the concepts that you are working with in your program. For
instance, imagine that you are tasked to write an application that
allows all your coworkers to vote on who they think should be the
employee of the month. You are most likely going to need code that deals
with the abstract concepts in a voting system such as a user, a vote,
and some code for grouping votes in a certain time period.

This kind of thinking and modeling is also known as domain modeling. The
problem domain is everything involved in trying to solve the problem. In
the preceding case, the problem domain is an employee-of-the-month
voting system. OOP is the tactical way of solving that problem by
splitting our problem domain specifically into domain models using
objects and classes.

In our example, our concepts, users, and votes are classes. Our code
will generate specific instances of users and votes and these are called
objects. In English, we might say \"*Mary (object) is a type of User
(class)*\" or \"*Bob (User) voted (Vote) for Suzie (User)*\". In this
chapter, we\'ll learn how to model this voting application while
learning the basics of OOP using classes and objects in Ruby.

Note

OOP is a large discipline and we will cover this topic in enough detail
to understand Ruby and learn how to build applications.


Classes and Objects {#_idParaDest-141}
===================

::: {#_idContainer262 .Content}
Classes are abstract templates for objects. You can also say that
objects are instances of classes. Classes contain the template for a set
of behaviors (such as methods) and data (such as variables). As
mentioned in the preceding example, at our company, we want to let
everyone vote, so we need a way to keep track of those users and we need
to model each user\'s behavior, such as the ability to vote. Here is an
example of how we can create a `User`{.literal} class to do this:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def initialize(name)
    @name = name
  end
end
```
:::

We\'ve created the base template for a user by using the
`class`{.literal} keyword and have given it the name `User`{.literal}.
Based on what we\'ve learned so far, we can tell right off the bat that
we have a `User`{.literal} class with a method called
`initialize`{.literal}, which takes an argument of `name`{.literal}. The
body of the `User`{.literal} class is concluded as usual with an
`end`{.literal} keyword. Additionally, we should note that the name of
the `User`{.literal} class is stored as an uppercase word, which means
it\'s a constant.

The `initialize`{.literal} method is a special method in Ruby that is
placed inside the class definition. In other languages, the
`initialize`{.literal} method is known as the \"constructor.\" This
method is called automatically when we \"instantiate\" this class,
meaning when we create objects from this class. The purpose of a
constructor is to \"initialize\" some state (such as variables) for
every object that is instantiated.

The user\'s name is stored in an \"instance variable\" denoted by the
`@var`{.literal} syntax. Instance variables are as the name suggests --
they are \"available to instances.\" We\'ll learn more about instance
variables in the next section. Let\'s first create an instance of the
`User`{.literal} class:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
u = User.new("Suzanne")
```
:::

Here, we\'ve created an object (that is, an instance) of a
`User`{.literal} class by calling the `new`{.literal} method on
`User`{.literal} and passing in the name as a string. We\'ve stored the
result of this method in the `u`{.literal} variable. Let\'s inspect this
object:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer219 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.1: Output for the initialize method
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.1: Output for the initialize method

[]{#_idTextAnchor147}

Instance Methods {#_idParaDest-142}
----------------

As we learned in the previous chapter with regard to the
`Time`{.literal} class, instance methods are methods that are available
on a specific instance or object of a class. Instances have states that
are held in instance variables. As you would expect, instance methods
have access to these instance variables.

We\'ve begun by modeling a `User`{.literal} class with its own class and
an instance variable, `@name`{.literal}. This isn\'t very useful by
itself, so let\'s add some useful methods (or behaviors), such as being
able to return the name.

Consider the following example:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def initialize(name)
    @name = name
  end
  def name
    @name
  end
end
```
:::

We have defined the `name`{.literal} method in the preceding snippet.
Now, we will invoke it, as shown in the following code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
u= User.new("Suzanne")
u.name
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer220 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.2: Output for the instance method
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.2: Output for the instance method

Here, we\'ve added an instance method called `name`{.literal}, which
returns the instance variable, `@name`{.literal}. Instance variables are
useful because they are held separately in each object and are
accessible to the object in any method. This is why you can assign the
variable in the `initialize`{.literal} method and access that same
variable in another method. Look at the following example:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
u1 = User.new("Suzanne")
u2 = User.new("Mary")
u1.name
u2.name
```
:::

The output would now show up as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer221 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.3: Output for the multiple instance classes
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.3: Output for the multiple instance classes

Let\'s add another method for updating the name:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def initialize(name)
    @name = name
  end
  def name
    @name
  end
  def set_name(new_name)
    @name = new_name
  end
end
u = User.new("Suzanne")
u.name
u.set_name("Suzie")
u.name
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer222 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.4: Modifying the instance variables
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.4: Modifying the instance variables

Here, we can see that we can modify the instance variable in a different
method and this is reflected when we call the `name`{.literal} method.


Getters and Setters {#_idParaDest-143}
===================

::: {#_idContainer262 .Content}
Since we are often getting (that is, retrieving) and setting (that is,
assigning) variables with objects, it\'s common to define the methods
that get and set those variables. In the previous section, the
`name`{.literal} method was a getter, and the `set_name`{.literal}
method was the setter.

Getting and setting variables are quite a common occurrence, and Ruby
has a number of different ways for us to set and get variables. One
quick improvement is to rewrite the setter method to use the assignment
operator.

Let\'s consider the following example:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def initialize(name)
    @name = name
  end
  def name
    @name
  end
  def name=(new_name)
    @name = new_name
  end
end
u = User.new("Suzanne")
u.name = "Suzie"
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer223 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.5: Output using = in the method signature
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.5: Output using = in the method signature

Adding `=`{.literal} to the method signature tells Ruby that this method
is to be used with the assignment operator.

If we try to call this method as a typical method, we\'ll get an
`ArgumentError`{.literal} error as follows:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
u.name("Suz")
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer224 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.6: Output with a typical method
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.6: Output with a typical method

Here is a very common idiom to define your class with some instance
variables:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  attr_accessor :name
  def initialize(name)
    @name = name
  end
end
u = User.new("Marlon")
u.name
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer225 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.7: Defining a class with instance methods
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.7: Defining a class with instance methods

`attr_accessor`{.literal} is a keyword that tells Ruby to define
\"accessor\" methods on the instance. Accessor methods are both the
\"get\" and \"set\" method for the symbol passed in. In other words,
they can be depicted as follows:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
  attr_accessor :name
```
:::

Note that `#`{.literal} is used as shorthand for `:`{.literal}. Let\'s
look at an example:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
  def name
    @name
  end
  def name=(new_name)
    @name = new_name
  end
```
:::

You can now quickly define lots of getters and setters just by listing
them as symbols to `attr_accessor`{.literal}, as shown in the following
code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  attr_accessor :name, :address, :birthday, :zodiac_sign
end
u = User.new
u.name = "Cleo"
u.zodiac_sign = "Libra"
```
:::

In the preceding format, you will notice that we left out the
`initialize`{.literal} method, which shows that it is optional.

As you can see, `attr_accessor`{.literal} defines both the getter and
the setter. However, there may be instances where we only want to define
one or the other, as shown in the following code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  attr_reader :first_name
  attr_writer :last_name
  def initialize(first_name)
    @first_name = first_name
  end
  def full_name
    #{first_name} #{last_name}"
  end
  def last_name
    @last_name
  end
end
u = User.new("Sophia")
u.first_name # Sophia
u.full_name # Sophia
u.last_name = "Khan"
u.full_name # Sophia Khan
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer226 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.8: Using attr\_accessor
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.8: Using attr\_accessor

In this case, we\'ve written a contrived class in which the first name
is immutable, meaning it can\'t be changed once the object has been
instantiated. However, we can read the first name, update the last name,
and display the full name by calling the corresponding instance method.

`attr_accessor`{.literal} is used when you want to have both a setter
and getter defined for you. `attr_writer`{.literal} is rarely used as
there aren\'t many cases when you want a class to write to an instance
variable but not have access to it. `attr_reader`{.literal} is very
commonly used to provide access to an instance variable but not allow it
to be changed directly.

Let\'s now solve an exercise to implement the `attr_accessor`{.literal}
method.

[]{#_idTextAnchor149}

Exercise 5.01: Modeling a Company\'s Organizational Chart Using Classes {#_idParaDest-144}
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

In this exercise, we are going to create some classes that model a
company\'s organizational chart. In a company, there can be many
departments, and each department can have many users. We will be
creating a model for this structure. The following steps will help you
to complete the exercise:

1.  Create classes to represent the company, department, and users, as
    shown in the following code:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class User
    end
    class Company
    end
    class Department
    end
    ```
    :::

2.  Add an initiating implementation for each class. We\'re iterating on
    these classes and adding functionality (that is, methods) as we go:

    Exercise5.01.rb

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    10 class User
    11 
    12   attr_accessor :name, :address, :department
    13   def initialize(name, address, department)
    14 
    15     @name = name
    16 
    17     @address = address
    18 
    19     @department = department
    20 
    21   end
    22 
    23 end
    24 
    ```
    :::

    <https://packt.live/2IWUf3v>

    As you can see in the preceding code, we have initialized the
    classes and specified the variables corresponding to each class. The
    `User`{.literal} class will be defined by the name, address, and
    department variables. The `Company`{.literal} class will be
    specified by `:name`{.literal}, company `:url`{.literal}, and
    `:department`{.literal}. Additionally, the `Department`{.literal}
    class will be defined by the `:name`{.literal} and
    `:users`{.literal} variables.

    Note

    We are using the Ruby library, `URI`{.literal}, to parse the company
    URL into a proper `URI `{.literal}object. The `URI`{.literal}
    library is available in the Ruby Standard Library.

3.  Instantiate a company by passing a name and URL to the constructor:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    c = Company.new("Acme Inc", "https://example.com")
    ```
    :::

4.  Instantiate two department instances by passing a name as the
    argument:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    sales = Department.new("Sales")
    engineering = Department.new("Engineering")
    ```
    :::

5.  Instantiate two users by passing in the name and address strings,
    alongside the department object instances, to the `User`{.literal}
    constructor:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    bob = User.new("Bob Smith", "1 Main Street", sales)
    mary = User.new("Mary Jane", "10 Independence Blvd", engineering)
    ```
    :::

6.  Assign department instances to the company through the department\'s
    accessor method:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    c.departments = [sales, engineering]
    ```
    :::

    To recap, we\'ve created a company that can be instantiated with a
    name and URL; a user that can be instantiated with a name and
    address; a department instance variable that holds a department
    object instance; a department that can be created with a name; and a
    company that can have departments assigned to it through its
    accessor method

7.  A company should be able to provide a list of all its users. Since
    this seems like it will be a common use case, let\'s write a new
    method for `Company`{.literal} that makes it easy to obtain a list
    of users. Since a company has a reference to its departments, we can
    simply iterate over the `departments`{.literal} instance variable
    and collect all the users in each department, as shown in the
    following code:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class Company
      attr_accessor :name, :url, :departments
      def initialize(name, url)
        @name = name
        @url = URI.parse(url)
      end
      def users
        departments.map(&:users)
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    However, can you spot the problem with the preceding method we just
    wrote? The observant reader will realize that if we map or collect
    users, which is itself an array, we will end up with an array of
    arrays. Luckily, Ruby provides a convenient method for dealing with
    this situation, called the `.flatten`{.literal} method. The
    `.flatten`{.literal} method takes arrays that have any level of
    nesting within them and flattens all the items into a
    single-dimensional array, which is exactly what we want in this
    case.

8.  Apply the `.flatten`{.literal} method to the `departments`{.literal}
    array, which itself is an array of users, as shown in the following
    code:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class Company
      # Other code omitted for brevity
      def users
        departments.map(&:users).flatten
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    Next, let\'s take a look at the `Department`{.literal} class. The
    `Department`{.literal} class has an accessor for `:users`{.literal}
    but, currently, it\'s possible that `:users`{.literal} may be nil.
    As good programmers, we want to protect against nil conditions where
    we can. If we protect against nil during object creation, it makes
    it unlikely or even unnecessary to write `if`{.literal} conditions
    checking for nil in other parts of code. This results in much
    cleaner code. To avoid this, we want to make sure that the
    `Department`{.literal} instance always returns an array when
    `:users`{.literal} is called. There are two approaches to this --
    seeding the user\'s instance variable at object creation or seeding
    the user\'s instance variable at runtime when called.

    The code for seeding the users instance variable at object creation
    is as follows:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class Department
      attr_accessor :name, :users
      def initialize(name)
        @name = name
        @users = []
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    The code for seeding the users instance variable at runtime is as
    follows:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class Department
      attr_accessor :name, :users
      def initialize(name)
        @name = name
      end
      def users
        # override the accessor, 
        # to make sure we always have an array to work with to avoid nil conditions
        @users ||= [] 
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    Seeding the user\'s instance variable during object creation in a
    constructor means that the `@users`{.literal} instance variable is
    set once and is slightly cleaner code. However, the approach of
    overriding the accessor has the benefit of only being called at
    runtime. If the `Department`{.literal} instance never has
    `users`{.literal} called on it, then the array is never assigned to
    `@users`{.literal} and saves on memory and performance. In this
    case, it\'s negligible, but if you are seeding with a large object
    or array, there is a considerable benefit to this approach. For
    instance, imagine if you were seeding the variable with data from a
    file. It is a very common paradigm to seed variables at runtime, as
    in the second approach.

    We will be using the second approach, where we seed instance
    variables at runtime for this exercise.

9.  Finally, let\'s add some behavior to the `User`{.literal} class. One
    thing that is missing in our model is that when a `User`{.literal}
    class is created and assigned to a department, the department\'s
    instance variable that points to users can get out of sync. We could
    maintain the relationship manually, which would require a lot of
    code; alternatively, we can add the user to the department\'s
    instance variable when the user is created. In the following code,
    we are following the second approach, where we assign the user to
    the instance variable of the department, when the user is created:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class User
      attr_accessor :name, :address, :department
      def initialize(name, address, department)
        @name = name
        @address = address
        @department = department
        @department.users << self
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    In the `initialize`{.literal} method for the `User`{.literal} class,
    we make a reference to `self`{.literal} and assign to it the
    `department.users`{.literal} attribute. We can do this because, in
    the `initialize`{.literal} method, `self`{.literal} is an already
    instantiated object. As we discussed previously when discussing the
    difference between `new`{.literal} and `initialize`{.literal},
    `initialize`{.literal} is actually called after the object is
    instantiated and allows for code to customize (or
    `initialize`{.literal}) the state of the object.

    This is distinct from other programming languages, where the
    constructor is responsible for instantiating the object.

10. Let\'s test the new class code we\'ve written, as shown in the
    following code:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    # setup data
    c = Company.new("Acme Inc", "https://example.com")
    sales = Department.new("Sales")
    engineering = Department.new("Engineering")
    bob = User.new("Bob Smith", "1 Main Street", sales)
    mary = User.new("Mary Jane", "10 Independence Blvd", engineering)
    c.departments = [sales, engineering]
    # play with new methods
    c.users
    sales.users
    engineering.users
    ```
    :::

    The output for the new class code will be as follows:

    ::: {#_idContainer227 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.9: Output for the class codes
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

    Figure 5.9: Output for the class codes

    Here, we can see that our data model is correct, as users are added
    to the proper department instance variable when the user is
    instantiated with that same department object instance.

11. Let\'s complete the data model by adding a number of relevant
    accessor methods and refactoring:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class User
      attr_accessor :name, :address
      attr_reader :department
      def initialize(name, address, department)
        @name = name
        @address = address
        @department = department
        department.users << self
      end
      # New method to keep the department's users up to date
      # when a user's department instance variable is changed 
      def department=(new_department)
        @department.users.delete(self)
        @department = new_department
        @department.users << self
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    As you can see, some of the data attributes are dependent on one
    another. For instance, a user\'s department should be consistent
    with the users in that department. This means that we need to make
    sure that when we change a user\'s department, we also update the
    user\'s attribute of that department.

12. We need to verify whether this works as expected. First, let\'s make
    sure we are set up again on an IRB console:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    c = Company.new("Acme Inc", "https://example.com")
    engineering = Department.new("Engineering")
    sales = Department.new("Sales")
    bob = User.new("Bob Smith", "1 Main Street", sales)
    mary = User.new("Mary Jane", "10 Independence Blvd", engineering)
    ```
    :::

13. Next, let\'s take a look at the users in the `Engineering`{.literal}
    department instance (we collect the `User#name`{.literal} attribute
    to make it more readable in the output):

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    Engineering.users.map(&:name)
    ```
    :::

    The output will be as follows:

    ::: {#_idContainer228 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.10: Output for engineering.users.map
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

    Figure 5.10: Output for engineering.users.map

14. Next, let\'s assign Bob (who was previously in Sales) to the
    `engineering`{.literal} department:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    bob.department = engineering
    ```
    :::

    The output will be as follows:

    ::: {#_idContainer229 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.11: Output after assigning a user from one department to
    another department
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

    Figure 5.11: Output after assigning a user from one department to
    another department

15. If you look at the preceding output closely, you can see that the
    `engineering`{.literal} department references both Bob and Mary.
    However, let\'s examine this on the console as well:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    engineering.users.map(&:name)
    sales.users.map(&:name)
    ```
    :::

    The output will be as follows:

    ::: {#_idContainer230 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.12: Output after assigning a user from one department to
    another department
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

Figure 5.12: Output after assigning a user from one department to
another department

We can see that both `engineering`{.literal} and `sales`{.literal} had
their `@users`{.literal} attribute updated appropriately.

Thus, we have successfully built a model for the company\'s
organizational structure using the `initialize`{.literal} and
`attr_accessor`{.literal} methods.

[]{#_idTextAnchor150}

Class Methods {#_idParaDest-145}
-------------

We\'ve seen how to create a class, instantiate it, and work with
instance variables and instance methods. Now, let\'s learn about class
variables and class methods. As their names imply, these are variables
and methods that operate at the class level rather than the instance
level. Since classes are templates for objects, class methods and
variables typically represent unchanging data or methods that belong to
that class and could apply to all instances of that class.

Let\'s start by defining a class method:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def self.roles
    ["Employee", "Manager", "Director", "Executive"]
  end
end
User.roles
```
:::

Here, we\'ve defined a `User`{.literal} class, which has a class method
called `.roles`{.literal} that returns an array of strings that
represent certain roles a user may have in a company. The method is
defined by prefixing it with the `self`{.literal} keyword. We call the
method directly on the class and thus we have a class method.

There are other ways to define class methods in Ruby, as mentioned in
the following sections.

[]{#_idTextAnchor151}

### Method 1: Calling a Method Directly on the Class {#_idParaDest-146}

A class method can be defined by calling the method directly on the
class. In the following example, we call the `.roles`{.literal} method
on the `User`{.literal} class:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def User.roles
    ["Employee", "Manager", "Director", "Executive"]
  end
end
```
:::

[]{#_idTextAnchor152}

### Method 2: Using the self Keyword {#_idParaDest-147}

In this method, the `self`{.literal} keyword is used to define a class
method. Take a look at the following example:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  class << self
    def roles
        ["Employee", "Manager", "Director", "Executive"]
    end
  end
end
```
:::

The first class method is very similar to the method we defined
previously. In fact, `self`{.literal} in `User.roles`{.literal} is
synonymous with the `User`{.literal} class constant. We\'re defining the
method on the class constant. Note that this syntax isn\'t used too
often, whereas `def self.<method_name>`{.literal} is the most common way
of defining class methods.

The syntax used with `class << self`{.literal} is used fairly
frequently. However, if you are searching for class methods, you won\'t
be able to distinguish them from instance methods, whereas in the first
invocation, you can search for `def self`{.literal} and find all the
class methods. However, proponents of `class << self`{.literal} argue
that to find a specific method, you don\'t need to worry about prefixing
the `self`{.literal} keyword in your search query.

[]{#_idTextAnchor153}

Class Variables {#_idParaDest-148}
---------------

Class variables are variables that belong to the class. Contrast this
with instance variables that belong to an object instance. Because class
variables belong to a class, and a class definition does not change,
class variables do not change either.

Note

It is not strictly true that class definitions and class variables do
not change in Ruby. Ruby is very flexible; however, the ability to
change class variables is strongly discouraged and is a highly advanced
topic, which is beyond the scope of this chapter. For now, consider them
as variables that are set up when loading the class constant.

The syntax for a class variable is the `@@`{.literal} sign, as depicted
in the following code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  @@roles = ["Employee", "Manager", "Director", "Executive"]
  def self.roles
    return @@roles
  end
end
```
:::

Here, we\'ve replicated our `User`{.literal} class, stored the user
roles in a class variable, and used the `class`{.literal} method to
return the roles. The class variable is available to us within the class
context or class methods, and it is also available to us within an
instance method:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  @@roles = ["Employee", "Manager", "Director", "Executive"]
  def self.roles
    @@roles
  end
  def initialize(role)
    @role = role
  end
  def get_roles
    @@roles
  end
end
u = User.new("employee")
puts u.get_roles
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer231 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.13: User roles
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.13: User roles

It is important to note that `self`{.literal} changes here based on the
context. For instance, consider writing a method as follows:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  @@roles = ["Employee", "Manager", "Director", "Executive"]
  def self.roles
    @@roles
  end
  def get_roles
    self.roles
  end
end
u = User.new("manager")
puts s.get_roles 
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer232 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.14: The NoMethod error
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.14: The NoMethod error

This is because `self`{.literal} in the instance method refers to the
object instance. When we defined the `class`{.literal} method, we are in
a class context, and `self`{.literal} refers to the `class`{.literal}
constant. If you want to call a `class`{.literal} method from an
instance method, you need to be explicit, as shown in the following
code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
  def get_roles
    User.roles
  end
  # or
  def get_roles
    self.class.roles
  end
```
:::

Note

You have to be careful about class variables in multithreaded or
multiprocess environments.

Class variables can be dangerous if they are changed by the code. The
class variable can be changed in one thread or process and not be
changed in another thread or process, and so you may get unexpected
results.

Note

Thread safety is a complex topic. You can read more about it at
<https://packt.live/2Mutq7S>.

It is very common for applications to provide links to share their own
web pages on social platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, or LinkedIn.
These are called social sharing links. There are many libraries and
utilities on the internet for doing this. Let\'s solve an exercise to
design our class in an object-oriented way.

[]{#_idTextAnchor154}

Exercise 5.02: Generating URLs for Sharing Content on Social Platforms {#_idParaDest-149}
----------------------------------------------------------------------

In this exercise, we will implement our own Ruby class that allows us to
pass in a URL and some other data and generate a URL that can be used to
share that content on a social platform. The following steps will help
you to complete the exercise:

1.  Create a new Ruby file.

2.  Create a class called `SocialShare`{.literal}. This will be the
    class that we use to generate social links for different social
    platforms:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class SocialShare
    end
    ```
    :::

3.  Create a class variable that will hold a hash of key-value pairs of
    social platforms with their social sharing URL templates. Each URL
    template will use a special Ruby syntax for replacing parts of the
    string with what\'s called a \"named placement.\" This is
    accomplished by using the `%{var}`{.literal} syntax. The
    `%{url}`{.literal}, `%{title}`{.literal}, and `%{summary}`{.literal}
    templates can be called by name to get replaced with another
    variable:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class SocialShare
      @@platforms = {
        facebook: "https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=%{url}",
        twitter: "https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=%{url} %{title}",
        linkedin: "http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=%    {url}&title=%{title}&summary=%{summary}&source=Recognize"
      }
    end
    ```
    :::

4.  Implement the `initialize`{.literal} method to receive the arguments
    necessary to share a URL. The arguments will include the platform we
    want a link for, the URL to share, the title for the post that will
    be shared, and an optional summary. Different platforms support a
    different set of options when it comes to the sharing utility. Our
    method will support these different styles, as shown in the
    following code:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class SocialShare
     # @@platforms code omitted for brevity
      def initialize(platform, url, title, summary = "")
       @platform = platform.to_sym
       @share_url = url
       @title = title
       @summary = summary
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

5.  Implement a `generate_url`{.literal} method that interpolates the
    template for the appropriate platform with the arguments used to
    initialize the object. To do this, we will use a special Ruby syntax
    that uses the `%`{.literal} sign as an operator. This is used in
    conjunction with the `%{var}`{.literal} templates we set up in *step
    3*. The left-hand side of the `%`{.literal} sign is the string to
    interpolate, and the right-hand side is a map of key-value pairs.
    The key should map to the named variable in `%{var}`{.literal} and
    the value will be the value that is interpolated into the string:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class SocialShare
      # previous code omitted for brevity
      def generate_url
        @@platforms[@platform] % {title: @title, url: @share_url, summary: @summary}
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    In the preceding code, we reference the `@@platforms`{.literal}
    class variable. Then, we do a hash lookup for the string template
    value for a particular platform set by the `@platform`{.literal}
    instance variable. So, for example, this lookup would look like the
    following:

    ::: {#_idContainer233 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.15: Output for the platform lookup
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

    Figure 5.15: Output for the platform lookup

    Here, we can see that the template string for the Facebook share URL
    is returned when we pass `:facebook`{.literal} as the key in the
    `@@platforms`{.literal} class variable.

    On the right-hand side of the `%`{.literal} sign is a hash where the
    keys are `:title`{.literal}, `:url`{.literal}, and
    `:summary`{.literal}. Essentially, this line is instructing Ruby to
    replace any reference to each of these variables with their
    corresponding values.

6.  Implement a reader method, `url`{.literal}, which memorizes the
    variable to an instance variable to make the usage more semantic and
    performant. We do this because we should expect the same output for
    the same set of parameters. Therefore, if we work with the same
    instance, we save the results to an instance variable for a quick
    lookup, as the `generate_url`{.literal} method will only be called
    on the first invocation:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class SocialShare
      def url
        @url ||= generate_url
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    This method is straightforward. We are using the `||=`{.literal}
    (which is pronounced \"or equal\") operator to memorize or cache the
    results of a call to `generate_url`{.literal}. The `||=`{.literal}
    operator is like saying *if not nil, then assign*. By memorizing the
    URL for a given platform and set of parameters, we are essentially
    making the instance \"immutable.\" This means it cannot be changed.
    Because we expect this object to never change once it\'s been
    instantiated, this means we can do performance enhancements, such as
    memorizing potentially long-running method calls. This particular
    method call to interpolate may seem very quick when run in
    isolation, but perhaps you are building a large web application with
    a lot of traffic that generates a lot of shareable URLs. This time
    can quickly add up.

7.  Test out the class\'s implementation by instantiating the class in
    an IRB session with different parameters. To do this, we will first
    set up some variables to represent the title and URL to share. Then,
    we will write a loop over all the platforms and make the appropriate
    method calls on each instance. First, let\'s take a look at our
    fully assembled class:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class SocialShare
      platforms = {
        facebook: "https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=%{url}",
        twitter: "https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=%{url} %{title}",
        linkedin: "http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=%    {url}&title=%{title}&summary=%{summary}&source=Recognize"
      }
      def initialize(platform, title, url, summary = "")
        @platform, @title, @share_url, @summary = platform.to_sym, title, url, summary
      end
      def url
        @url ||= generate_url
      end
      def generate_url
        url_string = @@platforms[@platform] % {title: @title, url: @share_url, summary: @summary}
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    Then, in an IRB console, let\'s set up some variables that we will
    reuse when testing:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    title = "Check out this great coding website!"
    url = "packt.com"
    ```
    :::

8.  Now, let\'s loop over an array of platforms (represented by symbols)
    and instantiate our `SocialShare`{.literal} class and call the
    `url`{.literal} method:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    [:twitter, :facebook, :linkedin].each.do |platform|
      puts SocialShare.new(platform, title, url).url
    end
    ```
    :::

    The output will be as follows:

    ::: {#_idContainer234 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.16: Output for calling the URL method
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

    Figure 5.16: Output for calling the URL method

9.  Next, let\'s add a class method to make it easy to call and get a
    share URL.

    We do this because it makes the usage of this class much easier and
    cleaner. The class method will be responsible for the code that does
    the actual instantiation of the class:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class SocialShare
      def self.url(platform, title, url, summary = "")
        new(platform, title, url, summary).url
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

10. Finally, let\'s add another class method that could be classified as
    a *convenience method*. This method will do what our test code does,
    looping over all the platforms and returning an array with the share
    links for each of them:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class SocialShare
      def self.get_links_for_all(title, url, summary = "")
        @@platforms.keys.map do |platform|
          url(platform, title, url, summary)
        end
      end
    end
    pp SocialShare.get_links_for_all(title,url)
    ```
    :::

    The output for the `get_links_for_all`{.literal} method will appear
    as follows:

    ::: {#_idContainer235 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.17: Output for a class with share links
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

Figure 5.17: Output for a class with share links

And there we go. We have written a class to generate share links on
different platforms. This class lends itself well to provide extensions
for other platforms. All you need to do is add to the class variable,
`@@platforms`{.literal}, and the rest of the code in the class will work
perfectly. This is the beauty of OOP. When you have a well-designed
code, it makes it really easy to extend functionality without having to
change a lot of other dependent code.


Inheritance {#_idParaDest-150}
===========

::: {#_idContainer262 .Content}
So far, we\'ve learned the basics of objects and classes, as well as
their class methods and variables, and instance methods and variables.
We\'ve learned that classes are templates for objects, and that we can
create classes to represent data and behavior that can be grouped
together in order to model a higher-level concept such as a user. This
allows us to keep our code clean, organized, and extensible.

Just as we\'ve learned that classes are templates for objects, we can go
one step further by learning how to use classes as templates for other
classes. This is particularly useful for when you want to have several
classes that all share common data and behaviors. Conceptually, think of
these \"subclasses\" as types of a class. A common example of this is
vehicles. Vehicles share characteristics, for example, they travel at a
certain speed, in a certain direction, and perhaps have a number of
wheels. A car generally has four wheels, a bicycle has two, and a boat
doesn\'t have any wheels, but all of them are types of vehicles.

When you create a class that serves as a template (or a base class) for
another class, this is called inheritance. Cars, bicycles, and boats are
all \"types\" of vehicles; so, we might have a base vehicle class and
then a subclass of the vehicle class to create each of the types of
vehicles, respectively.

When a class inherits from a parent class, it inherits both variables
and methods from the parent class. For example, the vehicle class might
define an instance variable for the number of wheels and an instance
method for calculating the speed. Since the subclass (that is, the class
that inherits from the base/parent class) is still a class, that means
it is still used to create object instances. The object instances from
the subclass, therefore, inherit those variables and methods, such as
the number of wheels and the speed. Inheritance is a fundamental OOP
concept and it is worth calling special attention to it.

As mentioned already, you can think about subclasses as being \"types\"
of the base class. In the following chapter, we will model people in an
organization. What are the common characteristics of persons in an
organization? At a minimum, they likely all have a name, an email
address, and a role in the organization. Can you think of other common
attributes or behaviors?

So, inheritance governs both data (that is, variables) and behavior
(that is, methods). Let\'s now dive into how inheritance works with
each.

[]{#_idTextAnchor156}

The Inheritance of Methods {#_idParaDest-151}
--------------------------

In the previous example, we had a `User`{.literal} class, along with
separate `Employee`{.literal}, `Manager`{.literal},
`Director`{.literal}, and `Executive`{.literal} classes. However,
employees, managers, directors, and executives are all types of users,
so we can use inheritance to share behavior among them.

Consider the following code snippet:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  @@roles = ["Employee", "Manager", "Director", "Executive"]
  attr_reader :address
  def self.roles
    @@roles
  end
  def initialize(address)
    @address = address
  end
end
```
:::

The preceding class describes a simple `User`{.literal} class with a
class variable of `roles`{.literal} and an instance variable of
`address`{.literal}.

Let\'s create subclasses of `User`{.literal} to describe each type of
user. To do this, we use the `<`{.literal} operator to subclass the base
`User`{.literal} class:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class Employee < User
end
class Manager < User
end 
class Director < User
end
class Executive < User
end
```
:::

Here, we\'ve defined `Employee`{.literal}, `Manager`{.literal},
`Director`{.literal}, and `Executive`{.literal} classes to \"derive\"
off of the `User`{.literal} class.

Let\'s now call the `address`{.literal} method on the variable using the
console, as shown in the following code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
e = Employee.new("1 main street")
e.address
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer236 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.18: Output for the inheritance method
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.18: Output for the inheritance method

Here, we see that the `Employee`{.literal} instance has inherited
several things. We did not define an `initialize`{.literal} method on
`Employee`{.literal}, but it inherited it from the base `User`{.literal}
class. It has inherited the `initialize`{.literal} method as well as the
`@address`{.literal} instance variable. Accordingly, any instance method
or variable you define on a parent class will be available on the
instance.

Now, take a look at the following code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  attr_accessor :first_name, :last_name, :address
  def initialize(first_name, last_name, address)
    @first_name = first_name
    @last_name = last_name
    @address = address
  end
  def label
    "#{first_name} #{last_name}"
  end
end
```
:::

In the preceding `User`{.literal} class, we have added some additional
accessors (`:first_name`{.literal}, `:last_name`{.literal}) and created
an instance method called `label`{.literal}, which returns a string that
interpolates those variables. Next, let\'s create our
`Employee`{.literal} subclass:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class Employee < User
end
```
:::

Now, let\'s investigate this on an IRB console. We will call the
`label`{.literal} method on the variables, as shown in the following
code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
e = Employee.new("Bob", "Smith", "1 Main street")
e.label
```
:::

The console would call the method as shown in the following diagram:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer237 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.19: Output for the inheritance of all variables and methods
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.19: Output for the inheritance of all variables and methods

Here, we can see that the `Employee`{.literal} subclass inherited all
the instance variables and methods.

Often, you will want to call the parent\'s method and customize it in
the subclass. You can do this by calling the `super`{.literal} keyword.
We\'ll learn more about `super`{.literal} in the next section.

Now, take a look at the following example:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class Employee < User
  def label
    "Employee: #{super}"
  end
end
```
:::

We can also call the base class\'s `class`{.literal} methods from the
subclass. Consider a `User`{.literal} class with the following class
method:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def self.types
    ["Employee", "Manager", "Director", "Executive"]
  end
end
class Employee < User
end
Employee.types # ["Employee", "Manager", "Director", "Executive"]
```
:::

`Employee.types`{.literal} will show up on the console as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer238 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.20: Output by calling the class method from the subclass
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.20: Output by calling the class method from the subclass

[]{#_idTextAnchor157}

The Inheritance of Variables {#_idParaDest-152}
----------------------------

Just as methods are inherited, so too are variables. The inheritance of
variables is important because data can be initialized in the parent
class and accessed by the subclass. As well as this, data can be set or
modified in the subclass and accessed by the parent.

Consider the following example:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class Employee < User
  def employee_email
    # first.last_name@example.com
    "#{@first_name}.#{@last_name[0]}@example.com"
  end
end
```
:::

Here, we are creating a convention for employee emails based on a
`first_name.last_name`{.literal} pattern. This shows that we have access
to the variables that were created in the parent class. We can also
modify the variables in the child class, as follows:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
e = Employee.new("Bob", "Smith", "1 Main Street")
e.first_name = "Bob"
e.employee_email 
```
:::

The console would call the method, as shown in the following diagram:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer239 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.21: Output for the inheritance of variables
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.21: Output for the inheritance of variables

We can take this two steps further by subclassing our subclass and
completely overriding the `employee_email`{.literal} method to
specialize its behavior in the sub-subclass:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class ExecutiveLeadership < Employee
  def employee_email
    "#{@first_name}@example.com"
  end
end
e = ExecutiveLeadership.new("Steve", "Jobs", "1 Infinite Loop")
e.employee_email
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer240 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.22: Output for subclassing a subclass
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.22: Output for subclassing a subclass

Here, we\'ve created a special type of employee called
`ExecutiveLeadership`{.literal} by subclassing the `Employee`{.literal}
class. Executives in our application get the coveted first-name-only
email address. Now, when we call `employee_email`{.literal} on an
`ExecutiveLeadership`{.literal} instance, it will still use the
inherited variables, but only use the implementation in its class.

[]{#_idTextAnchor158}

Calling super {#_idParaDest-153}
-------------

One of the advantages of inheritance is not only the ability to override
behavior and variables in parent classes, but also to customize them. In
order to customize them, you need the ability to call the parent
method\'s version of the method you are in and capture the result. The
`super`{.literal} keyword is what calls the parent class\'s
implementation of that method. It is called `super`{.literal}, because a
synonym of the parent class is a \"superclass\". First, we\'ll explore
`super`{.literal} in the `initialize`{.literal} method by modeling a
role class to encapsulate all the role-based functionality within this
class.

Take a look at the following example:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  attr_accessor :name, :address
  def initialize(name, address)
    puts "In User#initialize"
    @name = name
    @address = address
  end
end
```
:::

The preceding example is the standard `User`{.literal} class we have
been working with. It has been simplified to just have `name`{.literal}
and `address`{.literal} accessors and attributes. Now, let\'s create a
subclass that calls the parent class\'s implementation of
`initialize`{.literal}, as shown in the following code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class Employee < User
  attr_accessor :on_payroll
  def initialize(name, address)
    puts "In Employee#initialize"
    @on_payroll = true
    super
end
end
```
:::

In our `Employee`{.literal} subclass, we defined a new accessor called
`:on_payroll`{.literal}. Also, in our `Employee`{.literal} subclass,
we\'ve overridden the `initialize`{.literal} method from
`User`{.literal} and set the `@on_payroll`{.literal} instance variable
to `true`{.literal}. Then, we call the `super`{.literal} keyword. Let\'s
take a look at this on the console:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer241 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.23: Output for overriding the initialize method
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.23: Output for overriding the initialize method

We can see that when we `initialize`{.literal} an
`Employee subclass`{.literal}, the `Employee`{.literal} implementation
of `initialize`{.literal} is called first. Then, we see that the
`User`{.literal} implementation of `initialize`{.literal} is also
called, which is a result of us calling the `super`{.literal} keyword.

Another thing to point out about this code, which can often be
confusing, is when parent classes and subclasses each have access to
their respective instance variables and methods. Let\'s take a look at
this by way of an example of what not to do. Consider the following
code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def taxes
    tax_rate = 0.15
    salary * tax_rate
  end
end
class Employee < User
  attr_accessor :salary
end
```
:::

In the preceding code, we\'ve created an `Employee`{.literal} subclass
of `User`{.literal}, which sets employee users as having a salary
accessor. We\'ve also written our `User`{.literal} base class to have an
instance method that uses this accessor, `salary`{.literal}, to
calculate a relevant amount of taxes based on a fixed tax rate. Let\'s
take a look at this behavior in a console:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer242 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.24: Output of an instance calling its parent class method
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.24: Output of an instance calling its parent class method

This works as we expect. The `employee`{.literal} instance is able to
call its parent class method, and the implementation of the parent class
is able to access the subclass\'s accessor of `salary`{.literal}. So,
why is this bad code, or an anti-pattern?

This is an anti-pattern for a few reasons:

-   The parent class needs to have knowledge of the implementation of
    the subclass. If the subclass changes its implementation, this could
    break the parent class\'s code.

-   The `User`{.literal} class could theoretically be instantiated on
    its own. Then, it would give out an error referencing a salary
    method that doesn\'t exist, as shown in the following diagram:

-   ::: {#_idContainer243 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.25: NameError
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

Figure 5.25: NameError

[]{#_idTextAnchor159}

The Different Ways to Call super {#_idParaDest-154}
--------------------------------

There are several ways that `super`{.literal} can be called to call the
superclass\'s implementation. They are as follows:

-   Without arguments
-   With arguments
-   With the splat operator

[]{#_idTextAnchor160}

### Calling super without Arguments {#_idParaDest-155}

`super`{.literal} can be called without arguments as depicted in the
*Calling super* section. However, what\'s really happening is that the
arguments to the current method are implicitly passed to the
`super`{.literal} class\'s version of the method.

[]{#_idTextAnchor161}

### Calling super with Arguments {#_idParaDest-156}

If the arguments of the child class method do not match
`super`{.literal}, then you can explicitly pass the arguments to
`super`{.literal} (and thus the parent\'s `initialize`{.literal}
method). In the following code, we create another sub-subclass called
`Manager`{.literal}. `Manager`{.literal} is subclassed from
`Employee`{.literal}, which, in turn, is subclassed from
`User`{.literal}. We then call `super`{.literal} and pass in an explicit
set of arguments. This is usually done when the subclass method
signature has a different number of arguments to the super class\'s
method signature:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class Manager < Employee
  attr_reader :department
  def initialize(name, address, department)
    @department = department
    super(name, address)
  end
end
```
:::

[]{#_idTextAnchor162}

### Calling super with the Naked Splat Operator {#_idParaDest-157}

Earlier, we said that when calling `super`{.literal} with implicit
arguments, the method signature to the child class method must match
that of the parent. This can be somewhat limiting or cumbersome for a
child class to always have to be aware of a specific parent method
signature. Of course, Ruby provides a way around this with what\'s known
as \"the naked splat operator.\"

Take a look at the following code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class Employee < User
  attr_accessor :on_payroll
  def initialize(*)
    @on_payroll = true
    super
  end
end
```
:::

Here, the method signature just contains an asterisk (`*`{.literal}),
which is also known as the splat operator. As we learned in the first
section, the splat operator can be used to capture a varying number of
arguments. Since we don\'t need the variables in the child class method,
we can capture them as unnamed arguments, which will get passed
automatically to `super`{.literal}.

Note

This syntax is used occasionally and can always be written in a more
concise manner that is clearer to read, making use of explicit
parameters to `super`{.literal}. It is up to the developer to decide
which syntax is better to use for a particular use case.

Another way to understand the naked splat operator is to look at what
happens when you don\'t use it. Consider the following implementation:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def initialize(name)
    @name = name
  end
end
class Employee < User
  def initialize(name)
     @on_payroll = true
    super
  end
end
Employee.new("Mary")
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer244 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.26: Output when the splat operator is used
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.26: Output when the splat operator is used

So far, there is nothing special about this implementation. The
preceding usage is calling `super`{.literal} without any arguments and,
therefore, is implicitly passing the name argument to the superclass\'s
`initialize`{.literal} method.

However, imagine you work on a large application and there are many
developers also working on this code base. Another developer wants to
extend the `User`{.literal} class by adding an address accessor, as
follows:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def initialize(name, address)
    @name = name
    @address = address
  end
end
```
:::

Now, when we go to instantiate an `Employee`{.literal} class with the
same implementation as before, let\'s see what happens:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class Employee < User
  def initialize(name)
    @on_payroll = true
    super
  end
end
Employee.new("Mary")
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer245 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.27: ArgumentError for the Employee class
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.27: ArgumentError for the Employee class

The `Employee`{.literal} class\'s call to `super`{.literal} is sending
the same arguments to the `User`{.literal} class\'s
`initialize`{.literal} method as the `Employee`{.literal} class, and so
is only passing one argument. As such, we get the preceding error
telling us that we are not sending the arguments correctly. To fix this,
we could do either of the following:

-   Call super with explicit arguments
-   Use the naked splat operator

Consider the following example where we use the splat operator with the
`initialize`{.literal} method:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class Employee < User
  def initialize(*)
     @on_payroll = true
    super
  end
end
Employee.new("Bob")
```
:::

Here, the naked splat operator futureproofs us against additional
changes to the parent class, which is a good way to object-orient a
program:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer246 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.28: Using the splat operator
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.28: Using the splat operator

So, what happened here? We are getting an argument error because the
naked splat operator is simply passing along the arguments as given to
the `initialize`{.literal} method of `Employee`{.literal} straight to
`User`{.literal}, which is expecting two arguments. The code that calls
the subclass still needs to know to send the appropriate arguments that
the base class expects in this case:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
Employee.new("Bob", "125 Main Street")
```
:::

The console would respond to the call as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer247 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.29: Output for the Employee call
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.29: Output for the Employee call

In the previous sections, we modeled a `User`{.literal} class with name
and address instance variables. The address was represented as a string
variable. In reality, addresses can be modeled as more sophisticated
data structures. Let\'s conduct an exercise to see how that can be done.

[]{#_idTextAnchor163}

Exercise 5.03: Modelling a Class for Location Addresses {#_idParaDest-158}
-------------------------------------------------------

In this exercise, we will use our knowledge of OOP to model an
`Address`{.literal} class to give us a class that will split out the
different parts of an address into instance variables and also to add
some methods that make working with addresses easier and more useful:

1.  Open the Terminal and create a new file.

2.  Create the `Address`{.literal} class and expand on this by modeling
    a user\'s address.

    An address is made up of several components and can belong to
    different types of things such as users and buildings. So, we\'ll
    model an address with its own class, as shown in the following code:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class Address
      attr_accessor :street_address, :city, :post_code
      def initialize(street_address, city, post_code)
        @street_address = street_address
        @city = city
        @post_code = post_code
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

    We\'ve created a class for `Address`{.literal} that stores each
    component of a basic address. The preceding code uses a common
    pattern to define some variables as accessors and to initialize the
    class with those variables. This makes the resulting object very
    easy to use with a minimal class definition.

3.  Next, we instantiate the class in a Terminal:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    a = Address.new("25 Martin Luther King Jr Blvd", "Oakland", "94008")
    a.street_address
    a.post_code
    a.street_address = "5 Broadway"
    a.street_address
    ```
    :::

    The output will be as follows:

    ::: {#_idContainer248 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.30: Output for the Address class
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

    Figure 5.30: Output for the Address class

4.  Create an immutable class. You may want to make objects immutable,
    which means that they can\'t be changed once they are created. You
    can easily change this by changing `attr_accessor`{.literal} to
    `attr_reader`{.literal}, as shown in the following code:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class Address
      attr_reader :street_address, :city, :post_code
      def initialize(street_address, city, post_code)
        @street_address = street_address
        @city = city
        @post_code = post_code
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

5.  Next, we will be creating subclasses of the `Address`{.literal}
    class. We want to create subclasses of `Address`{.literal} because
    we want to model different types of addresses, such as international
    addresses, which have slightly different data and behavior.

    Most addresses have three basic components: a street address, a
    city, and a postcode. For addresses in the United States, you may
    also want to include a state. For Canadian addresses, you may want
    to include a province:

    Exercise 5.03.rb

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    26 class Address
    27   attr_reader :street_address, :city, :post_code, :country
    28   def initialize(street_address, city, post_code, country)
    29     @street_address = street_address
    30     @city = city
    31     @post_code = post_code
    32   end  
    33 end
    34 
    35 class UnitedStatesAddress < Address
    36   attr_reader :state
    37 
    38   def initialize(street_address, city, state, post_code)
    39     @state = state
    40     @country = "UnitedStates"
    41     super
    ```
    :::

    <https://packt.live/2IVYA79>

6.  Now, let\'s instantiate each type of address,
    `UnitedStatesAddress`{.literal} and `CanadianAddress`{.literal}, and
    inspect the Terminal to see how the instance variables look:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    irb(main):090:0> UnitedStatesAddress.new("1 Broadway", "New York", "New York", 10010)
    => #<UnitedStatesAddress:0x00007ffca2a87b08 @state="New York", @country="UnitedStates", @street_address="1 Broadway", @city="New York", @post_code="New York">
    irb(main):091:0> CanadianAddress.new
    => #<CanadianAddress:0x00007ffca2a84160 @country="Canada", @street_address=nil, @city=nil, @post_code=nil>
    ```
    :::

    The output will be as follows:

    ::: {#_idContainer249 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.31: Output for the different types of addresses
    ](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
    :::

Figure 5.31: Output for the different types of addresses

There are a few things to point out about the preceding code.

The `UnitedStatesAddress`{.literal} and `CanadianAddress`{.literal}
addresses implemented their own versions of the `initialize`{.literal}
method. Canadian addresses are constructed using a hash map, whereas the
`UnitedStatesAddress`{.literal} address has named parameters.

The `UnitedStatesAddress`{.literal} address calls `super`{.literal}
without any arguments, whereas the `CanadianAddress`{.literal} address
is explicit about the `super`{.literal} arguments. In the first case,
the arguments to `super`{.literal} are implicit based on the arguments
in the method signature of the subclass\'s `initialize`{.literal}
method. In the case of `UnitedStatesAddress`{.literal}, the method
signature is defined (`street_address`{.literal}, `city`{.literal},
`state`{.literal}, `post_code`{.literal}), but the base class had this
as its `initialize`{.literal} method signature:
`street_address`{.literal}, `city`{.literal}, `post_code`{.literal},
`country`{.literal}). In the preceding Terminal output, there is an
error -- did you catch it? The `post_code`{.literal} variable is
`New York`{.literal}. The reason for this is that the implicit arguments
are based upon the positional parameters.

In this exercise, we have created an `Address`{.literal} class to create
a data model that gives us more sophisticated functionality regarding
addresses that could not be achieved with a simple string. We also
created subclasses of this base class to give rise to special types of
addresses, such as different international addresses that require
special handling.


Encapsulation {#_idParaDest-159}
=============

::: {#_idContainer262 .Content}
Encapsulation is a fundamental concept in OOP that deals with keeping
some data (variables) and behavior (methods) private and protected from
the other code that interacts with our class. We want to design our
classes in such a way that we create a well-defined interface for them
that rarely, or never, changes. This is so other code that relies on
these classes is not dependent on the low-level implementation details
of those classes. Therefore, we need a way to designate whether a method
is public or private inside a class. In Ruby, there are three levels of
privacy (also known as visibility) of methods:

-   Public
-   Private
-   Protected

[]{#_idTextAnchor165}

### Public Methods {#_idParaDest-160}

This is the default level of the visibility of methods in Ruby classes.
When we define a method on a class, or use any of the `attr_`{.literal}
methods, such as `attr_accessor`{.literal}, `attr_reader`{.literal}, and
`attr_writer`{.literal}, we are declaring public methods.

Consider the following code for the `User`{.literal} class:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def initialize(email)
    @email = email
  end
end
```
:::

Here, we\'ve defined a `User`{.literal} class that can be initialized
with an email instance variable. As you can see (notice that we did not
define `attr_accessor`{.literal}), the `@email`{.literal} instance
variable is not accessible to anyone and is, therefore, considered to be
*encapsulated* or a private variable to the class:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
u = User.new("test@example.com")
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer250 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.32: Output for the public method
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.32: Output for the public method

If we define a method on the `User`{.literal} class, the method is
considered a public method and can be accessed by any code that has
access to the object, as shown in the following code:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def initialize(email)
    @email = email
  end
  def email
    @email
  end
end
```
:::

The output will appear as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer251 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.33: Output for the public method when accessed by any code
](data:application/octet-stream;base64,)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.33: Output for the public method when accessed by any code

[]{#_idTextAnchor166}

### Private Methods {#_idParaDest-161}

Often in our classes, we have several methods that are not meant to be
accessible to the general population of code. We only want to call those
methods from within the class itself. These are private methods. We
designate private methods with the `private`{.literal} keyword. As you
can see, the `private`{.literal} keyword stands alone, and all methods
that are defined below it within the class are considered private.

Consider the following example:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class BankAccount
  attr_accessor :transactions
  def balance
    calculate_balance
  end
  private
  def calculate_balance
    transactions.inject(0){|sum, txn| sum + txn }
  end
end
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer252 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.34: Output of the public method calling the private method
](./images/C14197_05_34.jpg)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.34: Output of the public method calling the private method

In the preceding `BankAccount`{.literal} class, we defined a
`public`{.literal} method balance that calls the `private`{.literal}
method, `calculate_balance`{.literal}. If we try to call the private
method from outside the object, we get a `NoMethodError`{.literal}
exception telling us we called a private method.

[]{#_idTextAnchor167}

### Protected Methods {#_idParaDest-162}

A lot of programming languages just have two levels of encapsulation:
`public`{.literal} and `private`{.literal}. However, Ruby provides a
third level called `protected`{.literal}. Protected methods are a middle
ground between public and private and are meant to give a moderate level
of encapsulation rather than going fully public or private.

Protected methods are declared in a similar way to `private`{.literal}
methods with the `protected`{.literal} keyword, as shown in the
following code snippet:

::: {.informalexample}
::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
Copy
:::

``` {.language-markup}
class User
  def this_is_a_public_method
    self.protected_method
  end
  protected
  def protected_method
    puts "This is protected but still accessible"
  end
end
```
:::

The output will be as follows:

<div>

::: {#_idContainer253 .IMG---Figure}
![Figure 5.35: Using the protected method ](./images/C14197_05_35.jpg)
:::

</div>

Figure 5.35: Using the protected method

What makes a protected method different from a private method can be a
bit confusing and requires a better understanding of the
`self`{.literal} method. Let\'s take a look at this in the following
exercise.

[]{#_idTextAnchor168}

Exercise 5.04: Demonstrate the Visibility Rules of Ruby Methods {#_idParaDest-163}
---------------------------------------------------------------

In this exercise, we will be using encapsulation and protected methods
to maintain the privacy of methods.

1.  Open the Terminal and create a new file.

2.  First, we create a class to work with that has a public, protected,
    and private method:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class User
      def public_method
        puts "This is a public method"
      end
      protected
      def protected_method
        puts "This is a protected method"
      end
      private
      def private_method
        puts "This is a private method"
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

3.  Let\'s call each of the preceding methods to see how they behave. We
    anticipate that the public methods are accessible to the outside
    interface of the object instances, while the protected and private
    methods are only available inside the scope of the object instance:

    ::: {#_idContainer254 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.36: Output for the method behaviors
    ](./images/C14197_05_36.jpg)
    :::

    Figure 5.36: Output for the method behaviors

    Here, we see that we can call the public method from outside the
    object, but we cannot call the protected method or private methods.

4.  Create a new method inside the class that calls each of the previous
    methods we created:
    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class User
      def call_each
        public_method
        protected_method
        private_method
      end
      def public_method
        puts "This is a public method"
      end
      protected
      def protected_method
        puts "This is a protected method"
      end
      private
      def private_method
        puts "This is a private method"
      end
    end
    ```
    :::

5.  Instantiate the object again and call the `call_each`{.literal}
    method:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    u = User.new
    u.call_each.
    ```
    :::

    The output will be as follows:

    ::: {#_idContainer255 .IMG---Figure}
    ![Figure 5.37: Output after calling each method
    ](./images/C14197_05_37.jpg)
    :::

    Figure 5.37: Output after calling each method

    Here, we see that each of the methods is accessible from inside the
    class. Let\'s make a small change here and use the `self`{.literal}
    method to call each of the methods instead.

6.  Revise the `call_each`{.literal} method to use the `self`{.literal}
    keyword:

    ::: {.informalexample}
    ::: {.toolbar .clearfix}
    Copy
    :::

    ``` {.language-markup}
    class User
      def call_each
    ```
